know that enterprise adoption of the

most companies now they pretty much have
decided they're going to do it
eventually what are some of the
challenges that enterprises see with
migrating yes some of the challenges
that we'll see first of all they have to
be ready culturally right it's a big
change when you go to the cloud because
it completely frees up how you do your
innovation and so you have to be
culturally Leddy to make that change
because it really feeds into your
product development process and it
really changes your whole organization
so you have to be ready organizationally
to make that change right second you
have to be able to build a business case
right because when you move to the cloud
you want to make sure that you're
getting cost savings and you're actually
achieving those benefits of being able
to scale and go fast and so you have to
build a business case on what stuff
moves first second and third market or
AWS recently bought a company called TSO
logic and TSO logic is designed
specifically to build those business
cases to help customers figure out how
to move and how to justify that move
once you've done that then you have to
take a look at your existing software
portfolio this is one of the bigger
challenges that we see from customers is
how do you actually move a whole fleet
of software from an on-prem world up to
the cloud and so what often happens is
they start to rationalize that software
portfolio so the first thing they'll do
is they'll take a look at software that
they want to keep this is software that
they've deemed strategic in nature it's
got a good fit on Prem as well as in the
cloud and it's usually got a skill set
built up around it and they want to
leverage that and so that software is
migrated and what we've seen is about
50% of that portfolio is actually in
that bucket now conversely we'll see
about 30% of software is deem strategic
but the customers will take this as an
opportunity to actually up level and
change that software so they might be
using a data warehouse and when they go
to the cloud they're going to say hey we
still need a data warehouse but we're
going to take this as an opportunity
to maybe do something different and so
they'll actually pick a different vendor
as they go to the cloud and then third
you know the remaining 20% that gets
decommissioned you know a lot of times
people use this as an opportunity to
rationalize their software portfolio and
it's a really good time to do that and
so they have to figure out how to
decommission that software so once
they've gone through that process they
then have to figure out how to migrate
that existing software because they
might still have a good use for it but
they have to move that from a perpetual
license to a consumption model and
that's not an easy task and so they have
to actually migrate that software then
they have to go buy new software for the
software that they're replacing and when
they do that they have to actually
implement governance along that whole
stack so there's a lot of intricacies
that happen when you're just moving that

mentioned government governance there I

are there with governance for enterprise
customers what what are the problems
that they run into yeah so what we'll
see is you know AWS wants to help our
customers have governance as they move
to the cloud and so what we're really
trying to do is give them a foundation
so that Wendy do this migration it's
it's a secure environment they have
compliance controls and they can also
have cost management and what we really
see is there's three aspects to doing
that so the first aspect is really
enabling that organization so how do you
actually enable your organization to
adhere those policies you then have to
figure out how to provision right and
you want to provision in a self-service
format because you don't want to slow
people down you want to provision and
allow them to move quickly and then
finally you have to figure out how to
operate that environment
so once you've stood it up then how do
you actually operate you know which
means how do you measure what's going on
checking the health of the system you
know what are those events that are
happening underneath everything and then
being able to diagnose problems is
necessary so the governance really gets
woven into all of those aspects as a
customer moves to the cloud so one final
question how do customers actually
implement some of these governance
policies on AWS yeah so if you take a
look at the enable provision and operate
type of model the first step is
enablement and what we'll see is
customers will use tools like AWS
organizations to actually set up groups
that they can then define who gets
access to what right they'll use things
like landing zones and landing zones
really provide that initial footprint
for customers as they go to the cloud
that they can start on the right foot
right we'll also see them start to use
newer services like control tower which
was announced at reinvent this year and
what control tower allows you to do is
really centrally manage all of your
policies
across all those different groups right
and you want to get governance up front
because a lot of times what
organizations do is governance is an
afterthought and they'll think about it
after they've got this stuff all out in
their organization and then they have to
implement it after the fact and that can
be very problematic and so we really
encourage customers to do that
governance aspect right up front
so you've got the right foundation
moving forward right so that's really on
the enablement part now when you take a
look at provisioning we'll see customers
use things like cloud formation so cloud
formation allows customers they actually
define best practice templates for
things that they want to deploy into
their univis environment they can then
take those templates in storm and
service catalog and so Service Catalog
is a repository for all those assets and
that also allows them to actually lock

give certain instance types to be able
to some people and some to the others
right they also use private marketplace
when they do that which really allows
